title: Brighton rocks to its literary roots
text:
Brighton rocks to its literary roots Brighton rocks to its literary roots ROB CROSSAN follows in the footsteps of some of the world’s greatest writers in a very English coastal resort. PUBLISHED: 10:27, Sun, Aug 16, 2015 | UPDATED: 10:59, Sun, Aug 16, 2015 ALAMY Brighton beach 
It is not too hard to imagine the man who wrote the dictionary reluctantly hurling his gangly frame into the waters in front of me. 
Of course it is unlikely that Dr Samuel Johnson had the urban seaside soundtrack of carousels and ice-cream van melodies anywhere near him when he forced himself into Brighton’s choppy waters in the late 18th century. 
Even on a bright summer’s day with clouds skidding across the East Sussex skies, inching a couple of toes into the slurping tide was enough for me. 
The chill factor is considerable. Following in Dr Johnson’s footsteps I headed into the warren of back streets with its Georgian town houses and bohemian taverns that have been frequented by some of the country’s greatest literary talents. 
I joined guide Jacky, from Brighton Walks, a service that celebrates the stellar roll call of authors who fell in love with (or in Dr Johnson’s case, rather disliked) the unique charms of what was, even back in Victorian Britain, one of the country’s premier seaside destinations. 
The place was, and in some ways still is, a prime source of inspiration and decadence for authors, philosophers, free thinkers and idlers. GETTY The Cricketers, one of Brighton's oldest pubs To luncheon at the Cannon Street Hotel. Followed by a weekend at the Metropole TS Eliot 
Walking along the seafront, the steep bank of pebbled beach piled below us, we pass the dark-red brick wedding-cake frontage of the Metropole Hotel, mentioned by TS Eliot in his epic poem The Waste Land when Mr Eugenides intones, “To luncheon at the Cannon Street Hotel. Followed by a weekend at the Metropole”. 
Eliot’s deft use of Brighton as a location for some of the grittier episodes in his masterpiece had precedents even then. Farther down the street sits the imposing Regency-style Royal Albion Hotel, scene of a particularly unpleasant chapter in the downfall of Oscar Wilde. 
This was where the police found the somewhat outrageous author after he engaged in a tryst with a young man on the seafront. 
It was a charge that was one of many used against him in the famous trial that led to him being confined to a cell in Reading Gaol. GETTY Pretty rural houses in Rottingdean 
However, it is in the heart of The Lanes, an engaging and bustling area of narrow streets just off the seafront, that perhaps Brighton’s greatest literary connection comes vividly to life. 
It was here, back in the late 1930s, that Graham Greene spent time in the town’s pubs creating the characters that would form the world of Brighton Rock, famously taken to the silver screen in 1947 with Richard Attenborough as the gang leader Pinkie Brown. 
The Cricketers, a stout, whitewashed building, has a Greene Room upstairs featuring framed letters penned by the mysterious author who notoriously never gave interviews. 
This was his favourite pub in Brighton, according to Jacky, although the famous scene where we meet Pinkie at the start of the story is almost certainly set in the Star and Garter which still exists though it is now called Dr Brighton’s. 
Greene may have depicted the town as flyblown but the man himself appeared to adore the place, once writing, “no city before the war had such a hold on my affections”. 
Sipping a pint in Dr Brighton’s I was fast becoming a convert myself to the atmosphere that still treads a fine line between plush bohemian hotel and bedraggled fruit machine arcade. 
Catching a taxi to head two miles along the seafront we arrived at the pretty village of Rottingdean. 
A game of croquet was taking place on the village green and an Irish setter bounded after a tennis ball outside a pub festooned with hanging baskets. The smell of freshly-cut grass made this the quintessential English rural scene that I thought existed only in the fantasies of George Orwell or John Major. Related articles Summer breezes back with a sizzling 81F 
This village was once home to Jungle Book author Rudyard Kipling who lived at a house called The Elms but who moved when his fame meant carriages full of visitors would stop outside and crane their necks to spy over the wall on the future Nobel prizewinner at work. 
The house is now in private hands but this year, to mark Kipling’s 150th birthday, the village is hosting a rolling series of plays, talks, walks and events to celebrate the place where he began to write his famous poems and tales from the Raj. 
Back in Brighton, with the sun slowly sinking and the shadows on the cobbled lanes lengthening, I made a beeline for English’s, a veritable seafood institution. 
It was a favoured dining spot for Charlie Chaplin and, more recently, Dame Judi Dench. 
The interior, bedecked in crisp white linen and with an ice counter jammed full of crustaceans, has the feel of an old vaudeville theatre dressing room. 
But the food has moved with the times. 
A focus on sustainable, local produce runs through the menu that takes in monkfish cheeks with sourdough bread, oysters from Mersea Island in Essex and a delectable plate of lobster served with lemon mayo and fries. 
Walking back to the Metropole, every figure in the fading light took on new and mysterious properties. 
Was that man in the dark suit Dr Johnson, struggling back to his lodgings? Or were the canoodling couple in a shelter Pinkie and Rose from Brighton Rock? In the words of Mrs Pipchin in Dombey And Son, the novel that Dickens wrote much of while staying here, “Brighton has proved beneficial. Very beneficial indeed”. 
Getting there: Hilton Brighton Metropole (01273 775432/hilton.com/brighton) offers doubles from £90, room only. Brighton Walks (07775 870195/ brightonwalks.com) offers a variety of walks, tickets £10. Brighton tourism: 01273 290337/ visitbrighton.com
